text:
CHRISTINE LIU: My
job title literally

says that I have to come up
with new ideas on the reg.

It's a super fun and
satisfying challenge, for sure,

but I need to confess,
there are days

where I am afraid there are
no new ideas in my brain.

I get hit hard with
writer's block,

or I feel totally trapped
in a creative rut.

I want to think of
something brilliant.

Maybe the idea is about how
I can't think of an idea.
No, no, that's lazy.
Or it's kind of meta!

And feeling blocked isn't just a
problem for the, quote unquote,
creative types.

Every job requires
a healthy dose

of fresh thinking and new
ideas, and it does not feel
good to hit that mental wall.

How do I break out
of a creative rut

to get those new
ideas flowing again?

And how do I avoid getting into
these ruts in the first place?
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Before we get
started, this episode
is brought to you by Microsoft.

Microsoft's mission is
to empower every person

and organization on the
planet to achieve more.

But it's nothing without
the people behind it.

Watch and read some of the
stories of the people behind
the mission at Aka.ms/Ascend.
[GROANS]

SONJA RASULA: I can't come
up with any words that
make any sense!

CHRISTINE LIU:
That's Sonja Rasula.

She's the CEO and founder
of Unique Markets.

They host pop-up markets
all over the country.

In her job, she comes up
with creative solutions,
big and small, on a daily basis.

SONJA RASULA:
People are so scared

of looking like they don't
know what they're doing--
[DRAMATIC MUSIC]

--or like they're not
happy or satisfied.
[DRAMATIC MUSIC]

When you then have a
creative rut, you're like,
there's something wrong with me.
[DRAMATIC MUSIC]

Maybe I don't know
what I'm doing.
[LOUD DRAMATIC MUSIC]

You start to ask
yourself these questions.

But I think it's totally
normal to have a creative rut.

We are not supposed
to do the same thing
for our entire lives.

For me, I really do probably
experience some sort
of rut once a month at least.

CHRISTINE LIU: I was
looking for a cure

to really prevent these
type of creative ruts,

but that doesn't
seem like it exists.
So they're just going to happen.

SONJA RASULA: If you
address that regularly,

then what doesn't
happen is what I

think a lot of people kind
of result in, which is like--

once or twice a year,
they have a major crisis.

And then what ends up
happening is, they burn out,

or they quit, or they
just don't perform well.

So I think it's
important to recognize

that not being
amazing at your job

all the time is totally
normal, and you just
have to reset yourself.

CHRISTINE LIU:
Sonja has some tips

for how to deal with those
smaller creative ruts

so that you hopefully avoid
the big creative crises down
the line.
All right, Sonja.

My creative fate
is in your hands.
Let's do this.

SONJA RASULA: The first thing
that I always like to do

is just reset, step
away from my computer--

and literally, this means
physically stepping away

from the computer and putting
on a song, like a hype song,
and just dancing it out.

And my employees
know that I do this.
Sometimes I get them to do it.
Often I don't, but I try.

But I just think you need to
restart the blood in your body.
You need to get moving.

You really do dance
like no one's watching,
and you just let loose.
[AIR HORNS]
[MUSIC PLAYING]

MAN: Rock and
roll, all day long!

CHRISTINE LIU: OK,
so the dancing tip

is really great to get you over
those smaller creative ruts

like hitting a deadline
or making decisions
during the day or whatever.

Now, the next tip is how
to deal with those larger
creative crises.

SONJA RASULA: Create a list
of why you love your job.

Why are you passionate
about what you do?

What makes you a
badass at what you do?

What are those skills
that make you unique

and make you really
good at your job?

As you are creating that
list, what happens is,

you start to recognize
and you start

to remember all the things
you love about what you do.

And as you do that,
you start to realize--

oh, the things that
I'm complaining about

are the reasons why maybe
I'm in a creative rut are not
a big deal at all.
[SCRIBBLING SOUND]
CHRISTINE LIU: Here's my list.
And I feel pretty good.

I think I'm good at
inspiring and mentoring

and setting others
up for success.

So I love that I have creative
agency and relative autonomy

over my work, finding
humor in most situations.

I will look back on
this list and remember,
I'm pretty cool, to me.

Honestly, with the list,
I will say it felt weird.

It's like writing a
love letter to yourself.
It feels self-indulgent.

Doing something
that introspective
is quite personal.

I should try it again,
but not for you guys.

SONJA RASULA: This is
probably my favorite,

because it's less like
chore-like than the list.

And it's a little more long
term than the dance moments.

Do something that is absolutely
not related to work--

cannot be related
to work in any way--
and something that is creative.

So you may have never
taken a pottery class.
Take a pottery class.

Or maybe you've never
sewn clothing before.

You're going to sit
in your apartment,

and you're going
to sew clothing.
[BIRDS CHIRPING]

CHRISTINE LIU: My activity that
I chose to do was gardening

and starting the
season off right.

So that meant
weeding a whole bunch

and planting a whole
bunch and just making

sure the plants are
happy, et cetera.
I am not a great gardener.
I am so hot and sweaty.

SONJA RASULA: You can
be good or bad at it.
It doesn't matter.
That's not the point.

The point is that you're just
having fun, using your hands,
doing something creative.
CHRISTINE LIU: Yeah!
Get it, plants!

SONJA RASULA: You almost
have to force these resets.

Otherwise, they don't happen,
and then no wonder everyone

is kind of in a creative rut and
also depressed, also anxious.

CHRISTINE LIU: So doing
something like gardening

is super fun, but
it's also the opposite

of popping a pill to get your
headache away or something.

It's not going to
solve or cure a rut.

But I think doing
something outside of work

is extremely healthy,
and over the long term,

creates the fertile
environment--

see what I'm doing
here-- for new ideas,

for taking a step back, seeing
things in a different way.

So after trying Sonja's
tips, I loved them, actually.

Because there are all
these things that I
do in pockets of my life.

But to have allowance
and to be like,
oh, yeah, there's value in it--
that's awesome.
So I'll try out anything.
Those tips-- I love them.
I suggest you try them too.

So those are Sonja's
tips, and I love them.

But everyone's
different, and I'm

sure you guys have
all sorts of ways

that you get out of
your creative ruts.
So I am all ears.

I want to hear what you do,
what you've tried, what works.
Bring it on.

Please leave them
in the comments.
I'd love to read them.

If you're still
watching, one, thank you.
But two, I'm really curious--
what do you want me to explore?

What problems do
you have at work?
I love to solve them.
Please leave a comment.
I'd love to hear your thoughts.

And if you have any other
ideas, throw them my way.
All right.
Peace out.
